title: Paul’s Final Exhortation
shortSummary: In 2 Corinthians 13, Paul delivers his final message to the Corinthian church, urging self-examination, faithfulness, and unity. He warns of the consequences of continued sin but encourages believers toward spiritual maturity and peace, closing with a powerful benediction.
timeline: c. AD 56-57 - Paul's Third Missionary Journey, shortly before his final visit to Corinth

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and author of the letter, delivering a solemn final warning and encouragement to the Corinthian believers.

keyCharacters.name: Corinthian Believers
keyCharacters.description: The recipients of Paul's letter, a church struggling with sin and division, called to self-examination and unity.

definitions.definition: Those who are rejected or disapproved by God due to persistent unbelief or unrepentant sin.
The process of building up or strengthening the church spiritually through teaching and encouragement.
A cultural greeting among early Christians symbolizing love, unity, and fellowship within the church.
The fellowship and shared participation in the Holy Spirit's presence and work among believers.

outline.heading: Paul’s Third Visit and Warning
outline.description: Paul announces his impending third visit to Corinth and warns that he will not spare those who continue in sin, establishing the seriousness of his message through the principle of multiple witnesses.

outline.heading: Proof of Christ’s Power and Call to Self-Examination
outline.description: Paul defends his apostolic authority as empowered by Christ and exhorts the Corinthians to examine themselves to confirm their genuine faith.

outline.heading: Paul’s Prayer and Commitment to Truth
outline.description: Paul prays for the Corinthians’ moral integrity, emphasizes his commitment to truth, and explains his use of authority for building up rather than destroying.

outline.heading: Final Exhortations and Benediction
outline.description: Paul encourages the believers to pursue perfection, unity, and peace, instructs them to greet one another with a holy kiss, and closes with a Trinitarian blessing.

application: Regularly examine your own faith and relationship with Christ to ensure genuine belief and spiritual health.
Pursue unity and peace within the church, remembering that God blesses harmony among believers.
Accept correction and discipline as means God uses to build up His people rather than to destroy.
Rely on the grace of Jesus, the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit for strength in daily Christian living.

keyVerses.text: Examine yourselves, whether ye be in the faith; prove your own selves. Know ye not your own selves, how that Jesus Christ is in you, except ye be reprobates?
keyVerses.significance: This verse calls believers to self-examination to confirm their genuine faith in Christ.

keyVerses.text: Therefore I write these things being absent, lest being present I should use sharpness, according to the power which the Lord hath given me to edification, and not to destruction.
keyVerses.significance: Paul explains his authority to discipline for the purpose of building up the church, not tearing it down.

keyVerses.text: Finally, brethren, farewell. Be perfect, be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace; and the God of love and peace shall be with you.
keyVerses.significance: Paul’s final exhortation emphasizes spiritual maturity, unity, and peace as marks of a healthy church.

keyVerses.text: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the communion of the Holy Ghost, be with you all. Amen.
keyVerses.significance: This Trinitarian blessing highlights the divine resources available to believers for spiritual life and fellowship.
